newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: SFE wheat jumps again on U.S., Australia weather.
newsitem.headline: SFE wheat jumps again on U.S., Australia weather.

text.p: Australian wheat futures forged ahead on Tuesday in response to Chicago's rise on Monday.
Volume was slightly more subdued with 11 lots changing hands, but prices moved ahead strongly.

May and July 1997 both traded higher by A$6.50 a tonne to A$192.00 and A$194.00 respectively. November 1997 and January 1998 also rose in floor trades, by A$7.00 and A$6.00 respectively to both end on A$190.00.
Settlement prices rose across the board with near-term contracts up by about A$4.50, November 1997 up A$9.00 and more distant contracts up by A$7.00 a tonne.
Most distant September 1998, easily the most volatile contract in recent weeks, leapt by A$30.50 to A$203.00 a tonne.
The Australian market was firming in line with Chicago, with Sydney Futures Exchange wheat futures were maintaining parity with Chicago values on a A$20.00 a tonne discount, he said.
Overnight, Chicago wheat futures set a new seven-month high in limit gains on severe damage expected from a weekend freeze in parts of the U.S. Great Plains hard red winter wheat belt.
Other brokers said that Australia's dry weather also continued to have a major impact on local prices.

The Australian Wheat Board's cash bid quotes for 1996/97 crop wheat and its indicator prices for 1997/98 wheat also rose strongly on Tuesday, by A$8.00 a tonne for Australian Standard White (ASW) and by A$6.50 for Australian Hard (AH), delivery Newcastle and Port Kembla in New South Wales.
Multi-grade indicator prices for ASW 1997/98 jumped by A$9.00 a tonne for both Newcastle and Port Kembla delivery.
